verses.verse: When they drew near to Jerusalem, to Bethphage and Bethany, at the Mount of Olives, he sent out two of his disciples.
And said to them, "Go your way into the village in front of you, and as soon as you enter, you will find a colt tied on which no one has ever sat, untie him and bring him.
"If any one says to you, «Why are you doing this?» Tell them that the Lord has a need for him, and immediately he will send him here."
They left and found the colt tied by the outside door in a place where two roads meet, and they untied him.
Some of those standing there said to them, "Why are you untying the colt?"
They replied even as Jesus had commanded, and they let them leave.
They brought the colt to Jesus and put their cloaks on him, and [Jesus] sat on him.
And many spread their cloaks on the road, and others cut down branches off the trees and spread them on the road.
Both those who went before and those who followed shouted, "Hosanna! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord!
"Blessed be the kingdom of our father David which comes in the name of the Lord. Hosanna in the highest."
Then Jesus entered Jerusalem, then into the temple, and after he had looked around at everything, now that evening had come, he went out to Bethany with the twelve.
On the next day, when they came from Bethany, he was hungry.
Seeing a fig tree away off having leaves, he came hoping if possible he might find some on it. But when he came to it, he found nothing but leaves, for it was not time for figs yet.
Jesus responded saying to it, "May no one eat your fruit from now on and forever." And his disciples heard it.

They came to Jerusalem, and Jesus went into the temple and started throwing out those who sold and bought in the temple. Then he overturned the money changers' tables and the benches of those who sold doves.
He would not allow anyone to carry any utensils through the temple.
He taught saying to them, "Isn't it written, «My house will be called by all nations the House of Prayer?» But you have made it a den of thieves."
The scribes and chief priests heard about it and plotted how they could kill him, but they were afraid of him because the people were astonished by his teaching.
When evening had come, he went out of the city.
In the morning as they passed by, they saw the fig tree withered from the roots up.
Peter remembering [what had happened the day before] said to him, "Master, look the fig tree which you cursed is withered."
Jesus replied and said to him, "Have faith in God.

"Truly I say to you that whosoever will tell this mountain, «Take up yourself and throw yourself into the sea,» and will not doubt in his heart but believe that those things which he has said will happen, he will have whatever he said.
"Therefore I tell you: Whatever things you desire-when you pray-believe that you will get them, and you will have them.
"When you stand praying if you have anything against anyone forgive them, so that you Father who is in heaven will also forgive you your wrongs.
"But if you do not forgive, neither will your Father who is in heaven forgive your wrongs."
Again they came to Jerusalem, and as he was walking in the temple, the chief priests, scribes, and elders came to him,
and said to him, "By what authority do you do these things, and who gave you this authority to do these things?"
Jesus answered and said to them, "I will also ask you one question, and you answer me, then I will tell you by what authority I do these things.
"Was the baptism by John from heaven or from men? Answer me."
They reasoned among themselves saying, "If we will say «From heaven,» then he will say, «Why don't you believe him then?»
"But if we will say, «Of men'...?» They feared the people, for all considered John to be truly a prophet.
So they answered and said to Jesus, "We don't know." Then Jesus answered saying to them, "Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things."
